pros: HR is quite helpful, that's it.
cons: NCS is not managed properly, and have no trustworthy data whatsoever. There is no intention to innovate the way the company works, and this causes processes to take ages. Further to this, mid lvl management is not interested in improving the way people work, but they would rather please their stakeholders with documentation that shows little to no actual value. There is a constant stress about capacity, but no data to evaluate it. The environment is chaotic and not worth the low pay.

review_title: role which expects a 20 hour daily commitment and only paid for 10-12

Inexperienced team leader, incompetent resulting in extra responsibility to senior mentors

pros:
Ok so if you want some experience working with young people, this is great. Expect to have a group of 15 (or more) teenagers who need to tolerate each other for 4 weeks. Expect to maybe be alone and have kids with additional needs. 
If you've done the program then you'll have a big heads up, if not then please take the time to understand that this isn't a chill 4 weeks of babysitting. Please do some research about safeguarding and first aid, what to do in an emergency or even just a mild inconvenience.
If you've got a group of kids and you're willing to put the time in to make sure theyr'e cared for, supported and will be kept safe, you'll have a great time. If you put your bossy britches on, your group will resent you.
cons:
Supervision ratios are dangerous! 1on1 mentors need to be a little more supportive and not just pass kids onto mentors who already have 15 others to support. 
There was a serious incident and one of my group had to go to A&E. The onsite staff went into shock and I had to deal with the issue alone, my co-mentor was too busy crying. Me and my mentor received little support afterwards.

pros:
- Immense responsibility from day 1
- Lead team of young people through the programme, ranging from different backgrounds 
- Support Worker - never feel like you're on your own
cons:
Depends on provider: 
- Little direction from managers in my case
- Provider scrapped in-house first aid training. Instead they've resorted to online training which is a more passive way of learning. Case in point - a lot of staff running around like headless chickens when a medical emergency did arise because they'd forgotten the online training completed prior. Not good enough when a young participant's life is in your hands.  
- Lots of guesswork & unable to answer questions posed by parents and young people in my team 
- Felt like I was blagging it at times

pros: Nice people to work with
cons: Long hours with potentially difficult kids

pros:

pros: really fun great pay and experience
cons: salary has decreased since the rebrand

pros: Great people and good values and culture
cons: Long hours and you aren't always paid overtime

pros: Lots of great support, and hands on experience
cons: Crazy hours and sometimes can feel isolating

review_title: Great job if you don't mind a challenge!
pros: Great colleagues, excellent training. You always have support from higher up colleagues and it feels very family-based. Very challenging but also a lot of fun. I worked as a support worker which allowed me to focus on just a few young people and allow them to get as much from the Programme as possible.
cons: Long hours, insufficient pay for the work which you do. You could be working constantly until you sleep, but this comes with the job.

pros: NCS provided an excellent culture of development with excellent pay and flexibility.
cons:
*NOT SPECIFIC TO EVERY PROGRAM* 
As NCS cohort management change as frequently as the mentors do, I must sympathise with their ability to learn the ropes, manage the employees and often challenging young people - HOWEVER, to do this best - you would at least have thought there would be some structure and organisation to their processes. 
During one of my numerous experiences, resources were non-existent or misplaced, rotas did not exist and communication was poor. 

*OTHER COHORTS I HAVE WORKED ON HAVE BEEN 100000x BETTER

pros: A group of excellent, smart and passionate people at working level. The mission is solid and the programme truly makes a difference in the lives of young people.
cons: The Senior Leadership Team needs development and the culture needs to be revived. Internal controls and governance need to be improved. T

job_title: Recruitment and Engagement Officer in Canterbury, England
pros: Introducing young people to adventure. Seeing them gain skills and experience new things. Travelling to range of schools and meeting a large social mix of people. and going out on programme.
cons: Poor pay for full time staff. Poor leadership from above. Presentations and scripts are cheesy. NCS doesn't care about young people, only numbers. Management have to much pressure to hit targets and the programme suffers as a result.

pros:
-Nice atmosphere
-Helpful colleagues

-'Worth it': what we do matters

pros:
- Very good experience for those looking to work with young people
- It is a fun job (adventure activities during the first week, uni halls and skill learning in the second, then charity work in the next two weeks)
- Build a great bond with the other staff and young people 
- Good, supportive staffing team
cons:
- Long work hours (especially during residential weeks due to night-duty). 
- Early waves aren't organised as well as the latter waves

pros: Staff are very friendly and I went as student everything was organised and planned to a T. The staff did cater to the children very well and  was helpful
cons: Some activities were boring and I did not like it . They had activities which sometimes was not suitable for some of the children

review_title: Innovative and supportive place to work!

cons: Full-on workload, but that comes with the nature of the job.
